#Text=2. Functionalized , Electrospun Nanofibers for Colorimetric Mercury Ion Detection
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=Direct Incorporation

#Text=To date , there has been tremendous progress made in the design and fabrication of nanofibers through the blending of inorganic/organic functional materials with polymeric materials followed by electrospinning to enhance the functional properties for specific applications .

#Text=The resultant nanofibers possess advantageous features , including being stable , flexible , lightweight , and mechanically strong from the organic polymers , while the incorporation of functional nanomaterials achieves the functionality .
#Text=Such electrospun nanofibers have shown tremendous applicability in the energy , filter , sensor , and biomedicine sectors .

#Text=Therefore , this approach can also be extended to fabricate the electrospun nanofibers through blending functional materials that are capable of detecting Hg2+ ions with a polymeric matrix , which is believed to preserve the functional characteristics .
#Text=To date , several functional materials have been incorporated in electrospun nanofibers for the sake of detecting mercury ions .

#Text=In this context , Kacmaz et al. have demonstrated the fabrication of ethyl cellulose ( EC)-based electrospun nanofibers for the sub nanomolar optical detection of the ionic mercury by using azomethine ionophore .

#Text=Briefly , the electrospinning precursor solution was optimized through varying concentrations of EC polymer , plasticizer ( dioctyl phthalate ) , room temperature ionic liquid ( RTIL , 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ( EMIMBF4 ) ) , and ( 4-(dimethylamino ) benzaldehyde2-[[4-cyanophenyl]methylene]hydrazine ( DC-AZM ) dye .
#Text=Furthermore , the precursor solution mixture was electrospun to obtain the composite nanofibrous membrane and was applied for the detection of mercury ions .
#Text=Owing to the high ionic conductivity , non-volatile nature , low toxicity , and chemical and thermal stability , the EMIMBF4 was selected as a polymer electrolyte .
#Text=Additionally , a thin film with a similar composition to the electrospun nanofibrous membrane was fabricated for a comparison of detection performance .
#Text=The DC-AZM dye turned the Hg(II ) ions into selective probes after the doping of anionic additive potassium tetrakis-(4-chlorophenyl ) borate in EC matrices .

#Text=The anionic additive plays a critical role in the extraction of Hg(II ) ions into the polymer phase ; meanwhile , potassium ions diffuse into the aqueous phase from the nanofibrous membrane thanks to the ion-exchange phenomenon , owing to electroneutrality .
#Text=The comparative response of the thin film and EC-based nanofibers to various concentrations of Hg ( II ) ions are illustrated in
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=.
#Text=The Hg ( II ) ions are responsible for the DC-AZM dye fluorescence intensity changes noted at 572 nm due to the collision and complex formation .
#Text=The nanofiber-based sensor has shown an enhanced response to Hg ( II ) ions compared to the thin film prepared using a similar composition , and the limit of detection was found to be 0.07 nM .
#Text=The high sensitivity observed may be associated with the higher surface area and the diffusion of mercury ions to the ionophores .

#Text=The response of nanofiber-based sensor has proven it an alternative technique to the cold-vapor atomic absorption spectrometry ( CV-AAS ) , inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry ( ICP-MS ) , and flame emission methods .
